abstract.p: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare life-threatening condition characterized by rapidly spreading infection in the subcutaneous tissues. Most of the time, the infection is precipitated by an event that produces a break in the epidermis. The authors report the case of a 55-year-old farmer who developed a necrotizing fasciitis of the left lower limb following a rat bite. The patient had serial debridement of his wound and broad-spectrum antibiotics and subsequent partial thickness skin grafting. His total duration of admission was 93 days. Early diagnosis, an aggressive wound debridement, and broad-spectrum antibiotics form the backbone of the successful management of this case.

body.p: Necrotizing fasciitis is a relatively uncommon infection of soft tissue that leads to a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissue and is associated with a high incidence of morbidity and mortality.1,2 In most cases, bacterial invasion and spread in the subcutaneous tissue follows an event that causes a break in the epidermis.3 Rat bite is rarely associated with necrotizing fasciitis, although it has been reported in the precipitation of foot ulcers in diabetics.4

sec.title: Case
sec.p: We report herein the case of a 55-year-old farmer who was admitted via our accident and emergency unit on account of a 1-week history of ulceration of the left lower limb following a rat bite to the left foot. The patient who reared rats for subsistence was bitten by one of his rats in a bid to escape. He presented to the hospital 12 days after the bite.

Examination at presentation revealed an acutely ill-looking middle-aged man who was febrile (temperature 38.8°C). His left foot and leg were swollen and tender with extensive areas of ulceration and blistering (Figure 1). No crepitus was observed. The patient’s popliteal pulses were palpable, and he could move his toes. He was not a known diabetic not on steroid medications and not immunocompromised. A diagnosis of necrotizing fasciitis of the left foot and leg was made. The patient was admitted and commenced on intravenous ciprofloxacin and metronidazole, and he also received intramuscular injections of paracetamol, the affected limb was elevated, and antitetanus prophylaxis given. Random blood sugar was normal, and a wound swab yielded no growth.

He had an initial episode of bedside debridement after warm saline immersion of the limb. When his clinical condition was judged stable, he had 2 further episodes of wound debridement in the theater. The patient responded well to treatment, and following good granulation of the wound, a split thickness skin grafting was done to achieve wound cover. His recovery was uneventful and was discharged home following wound healing. His duration of admission was 93 days.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe and often lethal soft tissue infection that may pose a diagnostic dilemma.5,6 Primary or idiopathic necrotizing fasciitis is characterized by the absence of an external portal of entry of bacteria, whereas secondary necrotizing fasciitis is precipitated by an event that leads to a break in the epidermis with subsequent bacterial invasion.3,5

Immunosuppression is believed to be an important predisposing factor for this condition, and diabetic mellitus is a common medical condition seen in patients with this infection.2,5 Necrotizing fasciitis, however, has been reported in otherwise healthy individuals.2 Our patient was a middle-aged man with no preexisting comorbidities.

Rats like other rodents can inflict bites that often are deep and can lead to serious infections. Organisms recovered from rat bite wounds commonly consists of those found in the rat’s oral cavity and those from the patient’s skin flora.7 Streptobacillus moniliformis and Spirillum minus form part of the normal nasopharyngeal flora of rats, especially wild rats, with S moniliformis being common in the United States and S minus more common in Asia and Africa.8,9 These organisms commonly cause rat bite fever in up to 10% of those bitten by rats.8 There is a close association between the incidence of rat bites and poverty.10 Our patient is a poor farmer who reared rats for subsistence.

The true incidence of rat bites in our country is not known since most minor injuries do not present to the hospital as self-medication is readily adopted to circumvent the cost of visiting a hospital. Most reported cases however are not community based but rather single hospital experiences.4

Both S moniliformis and S minus require specialized laboratory techniques for their demonstration.8,9 As these techniques are currently not available in our center, we were unable to isolate any of the organisms from the wound.

The treatment of necrotizing fasciitis requires a multimodal approach consisting of a prompt and often repeated debridement of all necrotic tissues and the use of broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotics.1,5,6 Some believe therapeutic modalities such as hyperbaric oxygen therapy and topical negative pressure may be considered for wound management.2,5 In spite of the modern advances in critical care, mortality rates in necrotizing fasciitis have however remained high (25% to 73%) because of the severity of the sepsis.5 A high index of suspicion will aid the early diagnosis of this condition.
